Body:
The aforementioned languages form a certain language union, although they belong to different language families and even branches.

The languages in question are all the Scandinavic languages (Swedish, Norvegian, Danish, Faroese, Icelandic) plus Finnish and Estonian.

The phonetic phenomenon in question conserns vowel-initial words with a glottal stop preceiding a vowel in an initial syllable.

The glottal stop is a sound occuring in vowel-initial words in some languages of the area which I hear as a glottal stop (similar to Arabic Ayn as pronounced in Saudi Arabic dialect).

In some isolated Swedish words the initial glottal stop is sometimes perceiveble, and sometimes not.

The Danish glottal stop is likely to be an enirely different phenomenon.

In Seto and VÃµro, until reicently regarded as dialects of Estonian, a glottal stop corresponding to Finnish Nom. Pl. marker -t (Estonian -d) is rendered with a letter q. That sound, however, (always?) takes a word-final position.

A glottal stop is sometimes perceived and articulated, and sometimes not, in Finnish vowel-initial words.

Are there any resourses / researches regarding initial glottal stop in Norvegian and Faroese languages?

Does Swedish initial glottal stop really exist (as that is the case with German and, to some extent, in Dutch)?

Is there a similar phenomenon in Icelandic?
Title: Is a glottal stop common for vowel-initial words in Fenno-Baltic and Nordic languages?
